title: Link error if panic_handler is marked #[inline]

labels.name: A-linkage
labels.description: Area: linking into static, shared libraries and binaries

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
Test case:
```rust
#![feature(core_intrinsics)]
#![no_std]
#![no_main]

#[panic_handler]
#[inline(always)]
pub fn panic_imp(_: &core::panic::PanicInfo) -> ! {
    unsafe { core::intrinsics::abort(); }
}

#[no_mangle]
pub extern fn main() -> i32 {
    panic!()
}
```

Compiling with:
```
rustc foo.rs -C panic=abort -O -C link-arg=-lSystem 
```

(This is on macOS; on other platforms you probably want different link args.)

I get:
```
  = note: Undefined symbols for architecture x86_64:
            "_rust_begin_unwind", referenced from:
                core::panicking::panic_fmt::h5e21b2f040947e1b in libcore-785d18b4fffac943.rlib(core-785d18b4fffac943.core.c3we4nte-cgu.0.rcgu.o)
```

In retrospect this error makes sense, since `#[inline(always)]` normally prevents a function from being instantiated unless needed.  But there should be an exception for lang items.

Without LTO, `#[inline(always)]` is futile anyway.  But with LTO, rustc can emit IR with the function marked `alwaysinline`, and the linker should respect that.

Edit: This also happens with just `#[inline]`.
